node.title: Victorian coroner to investigate Aboriginal woman's death in custody
node.alt: A close up of a sign that reads 'Dame Phyllis Frost Centre, Corrections Victoria'.
node.description: The 30-year-old womanÂ died in hospital on Monday after she was transferred from the Dame Phyllis Frost Centre in Melbourne's west.
node.content: ["The Victorian coroner will investigate the death of an Aboriginal woman who died in hospital after she was transferred from the Dame Phyllis Frost Centre in Melbourne's west.", "In a statement, Corrections Victoria said the 30-year-old prisoner was taken to Sunshine Hospital last week, where she passed away on Monday\u00a0surrounded by her family.", "\"The death of any person in custody is a heartbreaking tragedy and the team at Corrections Victoria sends its deepest condolences to the woman's family,\" the agency said in a statement.", "\"We recognise that all deaths in custody have impacts on family members, friends, victims and the broader Aboriginal community, and we're working to ensure they are provided with the support they need.", "\"The Aboriginal Justice Caucus was advised, and Corrections Victoria staff continue to work closely with the Caucus and the First Peoples' Assembly of Victoria.\"", "The women at Dame Phyllis Frost Centre are being supported and a smoking ceremony had been arranged, the agency said.", "The coroner will investigate the death and will hold an initial directions hearing within 28 days, in accordance with guidelines updated last year.", "Members of the woman's family are being represented by the Victorian Aboriginal Legal Service, whose acting CEO\u00a0George Selvanera\u00a0said he was \"so tremendously sad for this woman, her family and community\".", "\"No-one should have to deal with this trauma,\" he said.", "\"On behalf of the family, we ask everyone to give them space to grieve this loss. In time, there will be appropriate processes to examine what happened and the family will look for answers then.\"", "It is the second Indigenous death at the maximum-security women's prison\u00a0in two years, following the death of a Gunditjmara, Dja Dja Wurrung, Wiradjuri and Yorta Yorta woman in January last year."]
